Description: Ivory figure of dog with bronze fish in mouth: a superbly carved puppy wearing a collar which shows traces of gilding, with lop ears and long bushy tail which curls around its hind quarters, adopts the well-known posture of a dog at play with front legs bent and rump raised in the air. From its mouth protrudes a flat triangular piece of bronze with a notched end which is presumably intended to represent the tail of a fish he has just swallowed, although it might equally be a fly which he is just about to gobble down. The plinth is broken.
Curator's comments: The piece is brilliantly observed and belongs to a class of small carvings made towards the end of the 18th Dynasty, which portray animals that were familiar to and beloved by the Egyptians. It can have been made for no other purpose than to delight and amuse its owner. Bibliography: C. Andrews, 'Egyptian Treasures from the British Museum', 1998, pp.314, Cat. no. 100; 'Egyptian Treasures' [exhibition catalogue] (Shanghai, 1999), pp. 300-301 [95].
Bibliographic references: Andrews 2000 / Egyptian Treasures from the British Museum (p.236-237)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1991 8 Jan-24 Mar, Birmingham Museum and City Art Gallery, Man’s Best Friend
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
